subject: Re: [junit] RE: Separate Package for Test Cases or not ?
msgSnippet: ... Granted.  I was assuming that the set of unit tests theoretically provided by our imaginary vendor (has anyone ever seen a non-open source vendor do this?)
messageBody:
"Rogers, Jason" wrote:
>
> "David Stagner" wrote:
> > Unit tests document API usage very well, for starters. And they
> suggest
> > where any bugs encountered might be, even by their absence (a
> > problematic condition may not be tested, and a set of tests could
> rule
> > out a bunch of possible causes for a bug).
> >
>
> This seems like a pretty weak argument to me. They only document the
> set of
> the API that the authors chose to test, and they only test to the
> authors'
> degrees of comfortability. Truth be known, just because JUnit is in use
> does
> not mean that the code is being tested thoroughly. Right? You may be
> right
> that it could show you what isn't tested, but not necessarily why. And
> it only
> gives you a clue as to what is not tested and what is. There may not be
> a one
> to one mapping of the public API to the tests.

Granted. I was assuming that the set of unit tests theoretically
provided by our imaginary vendor (has anyone ever seen a non-open source
vendor do this?) would be reasonably thorough, complete, and
representative. If the unit tests don't exercise all the documented
methods and boundaries of the API, they're incomplete anyway. The hard
part comes with testing coupling, interaction, and state changes between
components, where the non-trivial bugs often lurk.

On a more philosophical level, i'd suggest that most unit testing is
either very useful, or mostly useless, depending on the confidence of
the programmer in the testing process. Cowardly testing is a sign of a
lack of confidence in the code. Once a programmer gets in the habit of
serious unit testing, the programmer will almost always be more
confident in the code - and thus more likely to test thoroughly. Good
unit testing is a self-reinforcing feedback loop. And if i were given a
set of unit tests from a vendor that clearly did not thoroughly test the
public interface of the software, i would immediately distrust the
software in question.
